clinical_study.brief_title: Lavender Oil Inhalation Help to Overcome Dental Anxiety Among Children
clinical_study.official_title: Can Lavender Oil Inhalation Help to Overcome Dental Anxiety and Pain in Children? A Randomized Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Recep Tayyip Erdogan University Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Recep Tayyip Erdogan University Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the impact of lavender oil (Lavandula angustifolia) on anxiety, pain and vital signs (blood pressure, heart rate and saturation) among children planned to undergone surgical intervention.

detailed_description.textblock: Lavender oil has sedative properties. Dental anxiety is one of the most common obstacles to dental care, especially for children ranges from 3% to 43% in different populations. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to investigate the use of lavender oil inhalation and to assess the correlation of anxiety and vital signs among children during a stressful surgical dental intervention. This study design was constructed according to the vital sign evaluations, anxiety and pain scores. Primary hypothesis was that of lavender oil inhalation prior to surgical dental interventions would affect vital signs and consequently reduce anxiety and perception of pain in children.

primary_outcome.measure: Vital Sign Measurements - 1 (sistolic and diastolic blood pressure)
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
primary_outcome.description: changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure pre-operatively, intra-operatively, post-operatively

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
primary_outcome.description: changes in heart rate pre-operatively, intra-operatively, post-operatively

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
primary_outcome.description: changes in saturation pre-operatively, intra-operatively, post-operatively

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
secondary_outcome.description: Five cartoon faces symbolized different emotions from very happy to very unhappy. The children chose one face at which they feel most like at that moment. One point is given to most positive face and 5 point is given to most negative face.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Scale 1 - Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
secondary_outcome.description: FLACC has five categories of behavior to rate pain as follows; facial expression, leg movement, activity, cry and consolability. The scores of each category are between 0 and 2. The total scores can change from 0 to 10 defined as mild (1-3), moderate (4-6) and severe (7-10).

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Scale 2 - Wong Baker Pain Rating Scales (WBS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion an average of 9 months
secondary_outcome.description: WBS combines pictures and numbers to rate pain. The scale has six faces assigned numerical ratings from 0 'no hurt' to 10 'hurts worst'. Administration of WBS is easy, not time consuming and requires minimal instructions

arm_group.description: 100 % pure, high strength lavender oil inhalation in a separate room for 3 minutes, prior to tooth extractions. intervention.description: Anxiety Face Image Scale (FIS) assessment in a separate room with face to face interview.
Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC), to assess objective operational pain after anesthesia injection and tooth extraction
Wong Baker Pain Rating scale (WBS), to assess subjective operational pain after anesthesia injection and tooth extraction
lavender oil inhalation in a separate room for 3 minutes prior to interventions
intervention.other_name: 100 % pure, high strength lavender oil inhalation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- being between 6 and 12 years of age
- children who are determined as Frankl 2, 3 or 4
- intellectually sufficient to complete the anxiety scale
- volunteer to take part in the study
- whose parents were willing to participate into the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- aged under 6
- has cognitive, cooperation (i.ex. Frankl 1) or systemic problems
- common allergies or dental pain
